question: Corduroy appearance on X-ray is seen in?
exp: Corduroy cloth appearance/ jail bar sign (veical striations in veebrae)-Hemangioma Hemangioma result of the replacement of normal cancellous by thickened veical trabeculae surrounded by fat marrow or vascular lacunae in veical intraosseous hemangiomas. It is a benign tumor and consists of vascular channels. It is seen commonly in middle-aged patients The spine is the commonest site Note: Polka Dot sign seen on CT scan

question: Ganga Ram a 19 years old male with a sho history of pain in the right groin that worsens at night time and has a small circumscribed sclerotic swelling over diaphysis of femur. Likely diagnosis is:
exp: Osteoid Osteoma - Night pain relieved on taking salicylates (NSAID) - Coical tumor "thickened coex" (CT) - In diaphysis shows Nidus- Lytic center with sclerotic margin Rx: Radio-frequency Ablation -Preferred X-ray CT scan

question: Which of the following most commonly produces osteoblastic secondaries?
exp: Most common tumor producing osteoblastic bone metastasis is carcinoma prostate. Purely Osteoblastic secondaries are produced by Ca.prostate, Ca.Breast, carcinoid tumor and medulloblastoma.

question: Treatment for fracture neck of femur in a 70 year old patient with avascular necrosis of head of femur?
exp: THA (Total Hip Ahroplasty) is usually indicated for the patients with a femoral neck fracture who meet the following criteria: Poor general health or frailty. Pathological hip fracture. Severe osteoporosis. Inadequate closed reduction. Displaced fracture that is several days old. Pre-existing hip disease (eg, rheumatoid ahritis, avascular necrosis)(of any age)

question: Monteggia fracture is a:
exp: Fractures between the proximal third of the ulna and the base of olecranon combined with dislocation of the proximal radio-ulnar joint. Direction of dislocation of radial head is used for classification. Bado's classification is used to classify monteggia fracture
opc: Fracture of proximal 1/3 of ulna with dislocation of proximal radioulnar joint
opd: Fracture of distal 1/3 of radius with dislocation of distal radioulnar joint

question: True about Salter harris classification is-
exp: Salter-Harris types Feature 1 Fracture line is entirely with in Physis causing epiphyseal slip 2 Fracture line extends from physis into the Metaphysis (Thurston-Holland's fragment sign) 3 Fracture line extends from physis into the Epiphysis causing epiphyseal split 4 Fracture line extends across the Epiphysis, (aicular surface), Physis, and metaphysis 5 Crush injury of physis with initially normal X-rays
opa: Thurston Holland sign is seen in type IV injury
opb: Type I injury has worst prognosis
opc: Type II injury is fracture of necessity
opd: Physeal crushing injury occurs in type V

question: Triple deformity of knee is classically seen in:
exp: Triple deformity is seen in tuberculosis of knee consists of ( Mnemonic PErF ):- P- Posterior subluxation of tibia Er- External rotation of leg F- Flexion at knee

question: Which of the following is not seen in scurvy?
exp: Epiphyseal dysgenesis is Seen in cretinism RADIOLOGICAL FEATURES OF SCURVY

question: Not true about stress fracture is?
exp: Pars interaicularis of 5th lumbar veebrae causing spondylolysis is commonest site in spine. Stress fracture Population at risk: Military recruits , professional dancers and athletes Patient typically complaints of point tenderness M/C in lower limb- 2nd> 3rd metatarsal (march fracture) M/C in upper limb- oleceron process M/C in spine -Pars interaicularis of 5th cervical veebra IOC-MRI Spondylolysis:
opa: 2nd metatarsal neck is involved in march fracture
opb: Olecranon is the most common site of upper limb stress fracture
opc: Pars interaicularis of L4 is common site in spine

question: Spina ventosa is seen in:
exp: TB Of Known as Phalanges Spina Ventosa Shoulder Caries sicca Spine Pott's spine TB involving the carpal bone is quite rare. Order of involvement of TB: spine (Paradiscal) > Hip(acetabulum) > knee (synovium)

question: Tom smith septic ahritis affects?
exp: Tom Smith ahritis:* Septic ahritis of hip joint in < 1 year old(infants) * Complete destruction of femoral epiphysis leading to hyper-mobile hip joint and instability.

question: Allen's test is for the patency of:
exp: Allen's test is for the patency of: Radial and ulnar aery> ulnar aery> radial aery In the modified Allen test, one hand is examined at a time: The hand is elevated and the patient is asked to clench their fist for about 30 seconds. Pressure is applied over the ulnar and the radial aeries so as to occlude both of them. Still elevated, the hand is then opened. It should appear blanched (pallor may be observed at the finger nails). Ulnar pressure is released while radial pressure is maintained, and the colour should return within 5 to 15 seconds. If color returns as described, Allen's test is considered to be normal. If color fails to return, the test is considered abnormal - suggests that the ulnar aery supply to the hand is not sufficient- indicates, it may not be safe to cannulate or needle the radial aery.

question: The lesions associated with recurrent dislocation of shoulder include all except:
exp: Bony Banka lesion is a fracture of the anterior inferior glenoid Hill Sachs defect Is a chondral impaction injury in the posterosuperior humeral head secondary to contact with the glenoid rim * Capsular laxity as well leads to recurrent dislocation of shoulder.

question: Nerve injury with Best prognosis ?
exp: Radial nerve injury has the best prognosis

question: In posteriorly dislocated elbow, most common nerve involved is:
exp: Due to location of the ulnar nerve i.e. posterior to the medial epicondyle, it is prone to injury in posterior dislocation of the elbow. Injury Common Nerve Involvement Anterior or inferior shoulder dislocation Axillary, (circumflex humeral) nerve Fracture surgical neck humerus Axillary nerve Fracture shaft humerus Radial nerve Fracture supracondylar humerus AIN > Median > Radial > Ulnar (AMRU) Medial condyle humerus Ulnar nerve Elbow dislocation Ulnar nerve Monteggia fracture dislocation Posterior interosseous nerve Volkman's ischemic contracture Anterior Interosseous nerve Lunate dislocation Median nerve Hip dislocation Sciatic nerve Knee dislocation C. Peroneal nerve

question: 12 year old boy presents with progressive swellings at upper end of tibia - irregular, local temperature raised, invariable consistency and ill defined margins most probable diagnosis is
exp: The clinical presentation in question can occur both in Ewing's sarcoma and osteosarcoma. However, swelling is around the knee joint at upper end of tibia, which ours the diagnosis of osteosarcoma (metaphyseal lesion). Ewing's sarcoma usually occurs in the diaphysis of the bone (middle of the shaft). Giant cell Tumor site- Epiphysis Secondary metastasis occurs in old age usually.

question: According to Denis classification, the middle column includes all of the following, except:
exp: Denis classificationof the structural elements of the spine: Anterior column Middle component Posterior complex Anterior pa of of the veebra and disc Anterior longitudinal ligament Posterior pa of the veebra and disc Posterior longitudinal ligament Posterior elements- pedicles, lamina, spinous processes, facet joints, and the remaining ligaments Association for the Study of Internal Fixation (ASIF) system reves back to the original two-column theory: Anterior column consisting of veebral body and disc Posterior column consisting of pedicles, laminae, facets and posterior ligamentous complex.
opc: Posterior pa of the veebral disc
opd: Posterior pa of the veebral body

question: 1st reflex to recover after spinal shock:
exp: 1st reflex to recover form spinal shock is bulbocavernosus reflex(S2-S4) It refers to anal sphincter contraction in response to squeezing the glans penis or tugging on the Foley( see figure) During lumbar injury,- If all reflexes are gone, then its spinal shock- If there is symmetrical loss +/- bowel or bladder involvement (which occurs in saddle anaesthesia), it is conus medullaris syndrome- If there is asymmetrical loss, then it is cauda equina syndrome.

question: A patient with swelling foot, pus discharge, multiple sinuses. KOH smear shows filamentous structures. Diagnosis is:
exp: Madura Mycosisis an example of superficial fungal infection. It consists of multiple species. Swelling with multiple discharging sinus Over mandible (or head - neck region) - Actinomycosis On Foot-Madura foot/Madura mycosis.

question: Most common osteomyelitis causing organisms in IV drug abusers?
exp: Osteomyelitis- M/C causitive organisms in i.v drug abuser is pseudomonas :-

question: A 15 yr school going student complains of moderate amount of occasional pain and swelling over the right knee joint. X ray was done which shows a lesion in right femoral distal epiphysis is suggestive of:
exp: Chondroblastoma and GCT are epiphyseal tumours. GCT occurs in 20-40th decade Chondroblastoma 8-16 years of age group . Mc site of chondroblastoma is epiphysis of the distal femur Xray - expansile, epiphyseal, slightly symmetrically expansile. Mimics synovitis C/F - pain and swelling. Biopsy :- Chicken wire calcification Rx curettage with bone grafting or bone curettage.

question: Onion skin periosteal reaction is usually seen in:
exp: Ewing sarcoma Destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an "onion skin" periosteal reaction. Originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Classically, PNET class of tumour, with c-myc positive,having round cells is histology. -Osteosarcoma show codman's triangle, sunray or sunburst appearance as periosteal reaction

question: Comminuted depressed fracture of the lateral tibial condyle is?
exp: Bumpers fracture- A compression fracture of the lateral tibial plateau, with separation of the plateau's margin or depression of the central aicular surface. Occur in a leg abruptly abducted by an automobile bumper, which strikes the lateral aspect of an extended leg and fixed foot, where the valgus stress forces the 2 bones into a close contact Pilon fracture is intra-aicular fracture of distal tibia at ankle joint. Plafond fracture occurs at the end of the shin bone and involves the ankle joint. Malgaigne's fractureis disruption of ipsilateral superior and inferior pubic rami and the sacroiliac joint.

question: From the following neck of femur fractures, which one has the worst prognosis?
exp: Garden classification Stage Description Image Stage I Incomplete impacted fracture(abduction fracture) Femoral head is tilted into valgus in relation to the neck Stage II Complete but undisplaced fracture Stage III Complete fracture with moderate displacement Stage IV Severely displaced fracture Worst prognosis

question: Fracture of lower one third of humerus impinging upon the radial nerve as it crosses from posterior compament to anterior compament crossing the lateral intermuscular septum is called as:
exp: There is a spiral fracture at the junction of the middle and distal third, is commonly known to be associated with a radial nerve palsy. This is called Holstein Lewis fracture. The radial nerve injury results in paralysis of the wrist, finger and thumb extensors (wrist drop), brachioradialis and the supinator. Essex-Lopresti fracture-dislocation is characterized by a fracture of the radial head, dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint and rupture of the antebrachial interosseous membrane. Thurston holland sign- also known as the shiny corner sign, is the small metaphyseal triangular poion of bone carried with the physis in type II and IV Salter-Harris fractures. Type II > Type IV

question: Arrange the following forces in order to reduce Dislocated shoulder using Modified Kocher's technique a. Adduction b. Traction c. External rotation d. Internal rotation
exp: KOCHER METHOD::::'TEAM' is the mnemonic used for forces required for reduction of shoulder using Kocher method. TRACTION force is given along elbow at first,then EXTERNAL ROTATION is given, ADDUCTION is given and then a click sound is heard as shoulder gets reduced,MEDIAL ROTATION (Internal rotation) and then splintage is given with shoulder

question: Tarso-metatarsal amputation is k/a?
exp: Mid-foot Amputation Type Level of Amputation Lisfranc Tarsometatarsal joint Chopa Intearsal joint (Chopa's - Intearsal = CIT) Pirogoff Calcaneus is rotated forward to be fused to tibia after veical section through its middle. Syme's 0.6cm above talar dome

question: A patient presents with pain in back. Lab investigation shows elevated ESR. X-ray skull shows multiple punched out lytic lesions. Most impoant investigation to be done is:
exp: Multiple Myeloma. Multiple punched out lytic lesions of skull Dx- M bands on serum electrophoresis. Elevated ESR is an impoant finding in multiple myeloma Punched out lesions of skull are seen in Eosinophilic granuloma-bevelled edges (double contour) Multiple myeloma.

question: A young boy presents with swollen knee, on getting hit over lateral aspect of knee and there was a twist while playing. Joint line tenderness was present. Anterior Drawer test done was negative. X-ray shows no fracture. Which structure is most likely to be damaged in the person:-
exp: Joint line tenderness goes towards medial meniscus. Anterior drawer test negative rule out ACL tear which can also be damaged in this type of forced and can be confused with. Symptoms include joint line pain, catching, popping and locking, weakness and giving way (instability) sometimes. Deep squatting and duck walking are usually painful. 1. McMurray's test is positive 2. Apley's grinding test is positive 3. Difficult to perform full squatting and toe walk in squatting position (Payr's sign) 4. Steinmann tenderness test. 5. Thessaly test 6. Ege's test (weight bearing McMurray test)

question: Chronic osteomyelitis is diagnosed mainly by:
exp: Sequestrum is the dead bone separated out from the living bone by the granulation tissue. The factors responsible for bone death in chronic osteomyelitis are: raised intravascular pressure Vascular stasis and small vessel thrombosis periosteal stripping bacterial toxins Sequestrum is the hall mark of chronic osteomyelitis Involucrum--periosteal new bone forming later

question: Which of the following is not true about osteosarcoma?
exp: Sunburst appearance is due to inability of periosteum to lay down new layer and instead the Sharpy's fibres (a matrix of connective tissue consisting of bundles of strong predominantly type I collagenfibres connecting periosteum to bone) stretch perpendicular to the periosteum. Lung metastasis is most common(15%) cases. CT chest is mandatory to rule out lung metastasis before sta of the treatment. It occurs in metaphyseal region with most common site being where the growth of long bones occur i.e. around knee(distal femur and proximal tbia) proximal femur and humerous. Secondary osteosarcoma occurs in previous bone lesions like Paget's disease, previous irradiation, bone infarcts,chronic osteomyelitis. This explaining its bimodal distribution with second peak in older age groups.
opa: Sunburst appearance due to bony involvement
opc: Seen in the metaphyseal region of the long bones
opd: Secondary osteosarcoma is seen in older age groups

question: Cod-fish veebrae are seen in:
exp: Codfish Veebra is seen in Osteoporosis > Osteomalacia Sickle cell disease Hereditary spherocytosis Homocystinuria Renal osteodystrophy Osteogenesis imperfecta Gaucher's disease

question: Commonest fracture in children:
exp: Most common fractures overall--clavicle > distal end radius Age wise Most common fracture at bih in neonates--Clavicle> humerus Most common fracture in children--greenstick fracture of forearm bones Most common fractures in elderly--veebral fracture > distal end radius fractures GREENSTICK FRACTURE OF FOREARM
opb: Green stick fracture of lower end of radius

question: Fracture of base of first metacarpal joint without dislocation is called?
exp: The Rolando fracture is a comminuted intra-aicular fracture through the base of the first metacarpal bone. This is a fracture consisting of 3 distinct fragments; it is typically T- or Y-shaped. OTHER OPTIONS: Bennett fracture- fracture of base of 1st MC extending into CMC joint usually very unstable due to pull of Abductor pollicis longus Jones fracture- fracture of base of 5th MT Boxer's Fracture- fracture 5th MC

question: Commonest site of occurrence of chondrosarcoma is:
exp: CHONDROSARCOMA It occurs over a broad age range: Peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma,and Between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma. Most are located in a proximal location such as: pelvis (most common site) proximal femur proximal humerus They occur in bones derived from enchondral ossification. Usually metaphyseal and central i.e. arising in the medullary cavity

question: All are true about Interochanteric fracture of femur except
exp: Interochanteric area - Extra capsular Fracture of Neck of Femur Inter trochanteric fracture Intracapsular Extracapsular Less common More common 60 years 80 years Ext. rotation < 45 deg |Pain Cx-AVN>non union | swelling | Ext. Rotation >45 | Shoening Cx-malunion more common
opa: Common than Fracture of neck of femur
opb: Treatment is Proximal Femoral Nail or Dynamic Hip Screw

question: Maffucci syndrome:
exp: Maffucci syndrome: 100% risk of malignant transformation Multiple enchondroma Hemangioma Phleboliths

question: The most common sequelae of tuberculous spondylitis in an adolescent is :
exp: The usual outcome of healed tuberculosis in spine is the bony ankylosis and in peripheral joints like Hip and Knee Fibrous ankylosis is seen. Note: Ankylosis-Abnormal stiffening and immobility of a joint due to fusion either by fibrous tissues or by bone.

question: 30 year old male who is positive for HIV and on antiretroviral therapy has pain in right hip region. Flexion, abduction and external rotation deformity of right hip for 2 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
exp: Stages of Tb hip: I.Stage of synovitis: The hip joint is held in flexion, external rotation and abduction causing apparent lengthening(FABER) Joint is in position of maximal capacity. II.Stage of early ahritis: Damage to aicular cailage sets in. Deformity: flexion, adduction and internal rotation(FADIR). Shoening<1cm. III. Stage of advanced ahritis: Fuher advancement of destruction and above clinical signs IV. Advanced ahritis with subluxation or dislocation. TB hip in HIV AVN hip in HIV Incidence More Common Less Common Deformity FABER-stage of synovitis may be prolonged on treatment, then subsequently with onset of ahritis - FADIR ensues. Limitation of abduction and internal rotation so initially position is adduction and external rotation (opposite to movements limited) and than subsequently with onset of ahritis FADIR ensues. Unilateral (usually) Bilateral (usually)

question: Regarding negative pressure wound therapy, false statement is:
exp: Negative pressure wound therapy: Enhances wound healing by the removal of fluid collecting in it. Suction pressure -75 to -125 mmHg Gives good granulation tissue Can be used intermittently or continuously Contraindications: Malignancy, Untreated osteomyelitis, Necrotic eschar
opa: Necrotic tissue with eschar in wound is a contraindication to its use

question: Chronic recurrent multifocal osteomyelitis is seen in:
exp: Chronic recurrent multifocal osteomyelitis Werner syndrome Waenberg's syndrome SAPHO syndrome Progeria Auto-immune disease Hereditary condition Mononeuropathy Associated - HLA B27 Not associated with osteomyelitis Synovitis acne pustulosis hyperostosis osteitis Premature aging increased risk of cancer entrapment of the superficial branch of the radial nerve Rx - DMARDS + steroids + NSAIDS.

question: The demonstrated abnormality is seen in paralysis of?
exp: In this video, the patient is waking lurching gait or a.k.a duck waddling gait. In paralysis of the hip muscles gluteus medius and minimus , the gait is described as "duck-like waddle(Waddling gait) or Sailors gait or Trendelenburg gait and consists of an inclination to the side on which the weight is born i.e. the normal side(lurching gait on both sides in case of bilateral involvement) B/L dislocation of hip from bih can also produce this type of gait. Gluteus maximux paralysis is seen in polio CROUCHING GAIT is seen. Trendelenburg test:It is impoant to understand the mechanism of this test to understand Trendelenburg gait. Normal two legged stance: Center of the gravity is midway between the two feet. Normal single legged stance: Center of gravity shifts towards the affected side. To allow this to occur efficiently, the pelvis iseffectively pulled up (by the motor) on the unsuppoed side and the centre of gravity is shifted directly over the standing foot. In clinical examination this is revealed by localizing and placing a finger on each anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS). As the patient stands on one leg the finger on the ASIS of the unsuppoed leg will rise. This is a normal response and would be recorded as Trendelenburg negative Pathology of the hip joint or paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus If the pelvis drops on the unsuppoed side, to avoid falling, the person has to throw his body towards the loaded side so that the centre of gravity is again over that foot. In this instance the finger on the ASIS of the unsuppoed leg will fall. Sound side sags: Mnemonic

question: Brodie's abscess is a terminology for:
exp: Brodie's Abscess: Seen in immunocompetent Host Long standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone (long standing because of strong defence mechanism of body). Involves long bones (metaphysis or diaphysis), e.g. Upper end tibia. Classical Brodie's abscess looks like a small walled off (Sclerotic margins) cavity in bone with little or no periosteal reaction. Usual isolated organism is Staphylococcus aureus (although most cultures are negative). Treatment:Immobilization and antibiotics for 6 weeks if the diagnosis is clear. When the diagnosis is unsure then an open biopsy is needed and the lesion may be curetted at the same time.

question: Which of the rotator muscle was not given its due impoance and was called Forgotten muscle of rotator cuff ?
exp: Subscapularis-:"forgotten muscle'' of rotator cuff- Internal rotator of the shoulder Difficult to pick up in MRI Diagnostic test done-lift off, belly press, Gerber test Nerve supply: Upper and lower subscapular nerves from posterior chord of brachial plexus

question: Commonest ligament injured in ankle injury:
exp: ANKLE LIGAMENT INJURY The most common mode of ankle injury is inversion of plantar flexed foot. Commonest ligament injured- Anterior talofibular ligament

question: Dematome of middle finger:
exp: For thumb C6 For index and middle finger C7 For ring and little finger C8
